Original_notes: (+); destroyed Babylon was reclaimed in this way
not farmers in general; only those who work for state or church estates
vinyards; one orchard of 2,400 fruit trees cited (p. 522); another with 10,000 (p. 523)
oxen pull plows; horses pull chariots
but cf. Olmstead (1923: 555); Nineveh - 120,000 probably fair estimate (Rawlinson 1871: 252); Rawlinson (1871: 256) estimates 175,000 for Nineveh
metalworkers located in NW corner of the city of Ashur
Dur-Sarginu formed an almost perfect square
good stone road, ca. 12 yards wide
"underground drains which displayed a sense for the need of sanitation"
only bitumen to hold fired brick in place (Olmstead 1923: 564)
enamelling of bricks (Maspero 1892: 199); interior of walls covered with fine plaster (Maspero 1892: 218); stucco (Maspero 1892: 207)
each craft had its patron saint and its chief, who was its direct representative with the government
metal currency was weighed (Maspero 1892: 291); coined money used (Olmstead 1923: 537-538)
each street had different kinds of good sold
scaling of contracts before a judge (Maspero 1892: 222); standardized weight of the mana used in commerce (Olmstead 1923: 281)
deeds on clay tablets filed in archive
apparently all in private hands; the ruling class looked down on commerce
"regular taxes", for which taxes in kind could be substituted (Olmstead 1923: 516)
family pledged by borrower in default of payment (Olmstead 1923: 543); self pledge (Olmstead 1923: 549)
veiling out of one's class was severly punished
yes, by royal charter in certain cases (Olmstead 1923: 513); apparently common (Olmstead 1923: 517)
council of elders municipally chosen, and governor appointed by the king (Olmstead 1923: 529); mayor (Olmstead 1923: 547,554)
began as palace hierarchy, evolved unto something more; it was hierarichal because there was a defnite order of protocol
"he is the supreme head of the national religions"
"thousands of persons are attached to the sovereign's household"
soldiers attached to soveriegn's household (Maspero 1892: 205); bodyguards (Olmstead 1923: 603); "1,000 picked soldiers" (Olmstead 1923: 604)
bowing low (Maspero 1892: 209), kissing ground before the king's feet (Maspero 1892: 280)
on New Year's day he must fast for the good of his people until the New Moon appears (Olmstead 1923: 602)
although a governor or qepu (resident) might oversee them (Olmstead 1923: 606)
"self help is legally confined to violations of family honour"
"the King always remained the ultimate court of appeal"
(-); encroachment of property meant triple restitution
slave by debt (Olmstead 1923: 539); "enslaved for crime" (Olmstead 1923: 540); had to work for the state (Olmstead 1923: 602)
some criminals tortured to death (Maspero 1892: 367); for sorcery (Olmstead 1923: 554); if family not turned over as composition (Olmstead 1923: 549)
there were prisons (Maspero 1892: 362); "a month in the king's service" (Olmstead 1923: 554)
sometimes, ruler leads, e.g., Sargon led Armenian campaign (Maspero 1892: 197); the Tartan (Maspero 1892: 277,319)
rab kisir, captain in charge of a kisru of 50-200 men, the normal tactical unit
defeated enemy warriors incorporated into Assyrian army
spearmen, bowmen, slingers cavalry [underlined] (Maspero 1892: 321-2); infantry (Maspero 1892: 320); charioteers (Maspero 1892: 322); sappers (Maspero 1892: 352)
(-); "every head cut off brings praise and part of the spoil to the soldier who brings it in" ?
heads [underlined] (Maspero 1892: 330); scribes register all the heads cut off (Maspero 1892: 332)
sacrificed to Ishtar, goddess of war
god of a city? (Maspero 1892: 199); Ishtar was goddess of Nineveh and Arbela (Maspero 1892: 211); patron saints for each craft guild (Olmstead 1923: 559)
apparently there was a priestess who interpreted the oracle of Ishtar (Olmstead 1923: 339); "seer… oracle" (Olmstead 1923: 601)

Sivan, lord of foundations (Maspero 1892: 196); gods of planets (Maspero 1892: 212); Merodach, god of fire (Maspero 1892: 238); Shed, god of death (Maspero 1892: 240); Nebo, god of intelligence (Maspero 1892: 289)
Hea, the sovereign of the gods (Maspero 1892: 250); supreme god, king of the universe (Maspero 1892: 295); Ishtar, all-powerful divinity (Maspero 1892: 292); Ashur (Olmstead 1923: 612)
(+); Sennacherib was distinctly "antihierarchical" in his attitude; Assyria never became priest-ridden
"god-king and the head of the official religion" (Olmstead 1923: 601)
King first deducts from booty captured from enemy a tithe for the temples (Maspero 1892: 211); provinces expected to make "perpetual ordinances of customary dues" to Ashur's temple
"earlier strata at Ashur… tulips in black on a pale ground" (Olmstead 1923: 561); "delicate painting… provincial centre as Nasibina" (Olmstead 1923: 561)
"enamelled picture" (Maspero 1892: 205); winged bulls painted on plaster (Maspero 1892: 209)
imported from Egypt (Maspero 1892: 272); glass ware with name of Sargon on it (Olmstead 1923: 561)
(-); "animals usually trod out the grain, at times the spiked sled was employed"
a kind of bellows, was in Egypt ca. 1500 B.C.
Aramaic alphabetic writing had come in, but it was very secondary to syllabic writing at time of Assurbanipal
a "learned instructor" taught Ashurbanipal to write (Olmstead 1923: 489); Assurbanipal received instruction in Akkadian and Sumerian (Olmstead 1923: 577)
celestial sphere divided into 360° (Olmstead 1923: 593); water clock to measure time (Olmstead 1923: 594); stretched cords (Drower 1954: 534)

of animals (Olmstead 1923: 511); men and goods (Olmstead 1923: 517); "Like the Romans, the Assyrians realised that the only sound basis for taxation is a census, and we have much evidence that the rulers made a careful check on both men and their products" (Olmstead 1923: 517)
papyrus brought from Egypt - skins for writing made locally (Maspero 1892: 287); "skins prepared for parchment (Olmstead 1923: 560)
